text.p: These are some of the main stories in Sofia newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- The Bulgarian National Bank's (BNB) Issue Department assets and liabilities fell to 3.117 billion marks on July 25 from 3.196 billion marks a week earlier, BNB figures showed.

-- A group of Bulgarian government and army experts is expected to discuss by the week's end whether Bulgaria should destroy its eight SS 23 tactical warfare missile, Foreign Minister Nadezhda Mihailova said. @
-- Bulgaria's Bank Consolidation Company's (BCC) shareholders elected Petar Zhotev as the BCC executive director.
-- Bulgaria's central government budget deficit fell by some 5.82 billion levs in the first half of July to 429.94 billion levs or 45.6 percent of the annual target, Finance Ministry figures showed.

-- Bulgaria will draw down by end-month on some $138 million International Monetary Fund standby loan instalment released last week to cover payments made to foreign creditors, BNB governor Svetoslav Gavriiski said. @
-- Bulgaria's cabinet approved a draft bill authorising the use of eavesdropping and audio- and video recording in investigation of violent crimes, Interior Minister Bogomil Bonev said.
-- Bulgaria's Finance Ministry has transferred some $131 million to cover coupon payments on its Brady bonds, deputy Finance Minister Plamen Oresharski said.
-- Bulgaria's cabinet decided to raise natural gas prices by 7.06 percent and central heating charges by 7.7 percent from August 1, state Energy Price Commission chairman Mladen Mladenov said.

-- Bulgaria's National Investigation Service has issued a list of 1581 Bulgarians who should be banned from travelling abroad on suspected involvement in organised crime and corruption cases, state national radio said.

-- Bulgaria's Privatisation Agency said it had sold 24.4 percent stake in Bulgaria's timber processing plant Lesoplast for $1.1 million to the Vienna-based firm Welde GmbH. -- Sofia Newsroom, (++359-2) 981 4145
